client_profile: Family of three looking to buy a property in Brussels. Budget is EUR 730,000 to EUR 1,090,000. Prioritizing restaurants, parks, expat community, and central access.
must_have: Proximity to parks and green spaces
red_flags: Potentially inflated prices in central areas
contradictions: Budget may limit access to preferred districts
Desirable areas may lack larger homes
Taste for urban amenities vs. residential comfort
Interest in expat community vs. local integration

top_districts.name: Etterbeek
why: Nearby Cinquantenaire park is perfect for family outings.
Strong access to restaurants in lively Jourdan area.
watch_out: Rents near EU quarter can be higher; traffic around main axes.

top_districts.name: City of Brussels
why: Royal Palace area offers cultural attractions and parks.
Dynamic restaurant scene around Sablon is family-friendly.
watch_out: Touristy pockets and traffic can feel noisy on weekends.

top_districts.name: Ixelles
why: Flagey area is vibrant with cafes and parks for families.
Accessible public transport facilitates easy city travel.
watch_out: Popular streets get noisy on weekends; parking is often tight.

questions_for_agent_landlord: What are the total costs involved in the purchase?
Are there any ongoing building charges or planned works?
How does the property comply with local regulations?
What is the condition of the property and when can I inspect?
What is the expected timeline for negotiations and closing?
next_steps: Review potential properties in preferred districts.
Discuss financial options with a local bank.
Engage with a real estate agent for support.
clarifying_questions: Are there any specific school preferences?
Do you have a preference for new or older properties?
What is your ideal commute time to work?
